message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The depigmented skin patches that fluorescence blue-white under Wood's lamp are characteristic of vitiligo, which is an autoimmune disorder. Elevated anti-TPO antibody levels are commonly seen in autoimmune thyroid disease, which is associated with vitiligo. Option A describes the “Spaghetti and meatballs” appearance seen in fungal infections, not vitiligo. Option B describes another condition called albinism that is characterized by low pigment production and normal melanocyte count, but it is not associated with vitiligo. Option D describes a finding seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis, which is a completely different condition not associated with vitiligo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blue-white fluorescence under Wood's lamp indicates the presence of vitiligo, which is caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. Among the options, only option (C) is associated with autoimmune disorders. Option (A) describes the appearance of dermatophyte infections. Option (B) describes albinism. Option (D) describes a type of tumor that is usually present in patients with tuberous sclerosis, which is not associated with vitiligo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesions and fluorescence under Wood's lamp suggest the diagnosis of vitiligo. Choice C, elevated anti-TPO antibody levels, is most likely associated with vitiligo as it is an autoimmune disorder that affects melanocytes. Choice A, “Spaghetti and meatballs” appearance on KOH scraping, is associated with tinea versicolor. Choice B, decreased pigment with normal melanocyte count, is associated with albinism. Choice D, renal angiomyolipoma, is associated with tuberous sclerosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The depigmented skin patches and fluorescence under Wood's lamp indicate a diagnosis of vitiligo. Among the options, only elevated anti-TPO antibody levels are associated with vitiligo. Option A is associated with tinea versicolor, option B is associated with albinism or piebaldism, and option D is associated with tuberous sclerosis complex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest vitiligo, which is associated with autoimmune disorders such as Hashimoto’s thyroiditis and elevated anti-TPO antibody levels. "Spaghetti and meatballs" appearance on KOH scraping is associated with tinea versicolor, decreased pigment with normal melanocyte count is associated with albinism, and renal angiomyolipoma is associated with tuberous sclerosis complex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest the patient has vitiligo, a condition that causes depigmentation of the skin. Elevated anti-TPO antibody levels are commonly seen in association with vitiligo. "Spaghetti and meatballs" appearance on KOH scraping is a characteristic finding in tinea versicolor, which causes hyperpigmented or hypopigmented patches on the skin and does not fluoresce under Wood's lamp. Decreased pigment with normal melanocyte count suggests albinism. Renal angiomyolipoma on abdominal MRI is associated with tuberous sclerosis, which can present with skin abnormalities such as ash-leaf spots, but not specifically with vitiligo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are characteristic of vitiligo, which is an autoimmune disorder. Elevated anti-TPO antibody levels are commonly seen in patients with vitiligo. Options A and B are associated with fungal infections and albinism, respectively. Option D is associated with tuberous sclerosis, which is not related to vitiligo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesions and their fluorescence under Wood’s lamp suggest vitiligo. Among the options, only elevated anti-TPO antibody levels are associated with vitiligo. “Spaghetti and meatballs” appearance on KOH scraping suggests tinea versicolor, decreased pigment with normal melanocyte count suggests albinism, and renal angiomyolipoma on abdominal MRI suggests tuberous sclerosis complex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lightening of the skin, especially in specific areas, and the blue-white fluorescence under Wood's lamp suggest a diagnosis of vitiligo. Elevated anti-TPO antibody levels are associated with autoimmune diseases like vitiligo. Option A is related to fungal infections, option B is related to albinism, and option D is related to tuberous sclerosis, which are all not associated with the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The depigmented patches, lack of symptoms, and fluorescence under Wood’s lamp indicate a diagnosis of vitiligo. Elevated anti-TPO antibody levels are associated with autoimmune thyroid disease, which occurs more frequently in patients with vitiligo. "Spaghetti and meatballs" appearance on KOH scraping is associated with tinea versicolor, which does not cause depigmented patches. Decreased pigment with normal melanocyte count is associated with albinism, which is a congenital condition. Renal angiomyolipoma is associated with tuberous sclerosis complex, which presents with hamartomas in multiple organs but not with depigmented patches.
